prompt.p: A 15-year-old girl presents with a 1-year history of cyclical lower abdominal pain. She has not undergone menarche and denies having sexual intercourse. On examination, she has normal secondary sexual characteristics. Per vaginal inspection reveals a bulging blue domed translucent membrane. Oestradiol levels are normal.
What is the most appropriate diagnosis?

modalFeedback.p: Option B is Correct. The blue domed mass is menstrual blood sequestered behind an intact hymen. This requires incision to evacuate the vaginal and uterine content.
Option A is Incorrect , The patient has developed secondary sexual characteristics. These would be lacking if this option was true.
Option C is Incorrect. This can result in amenorrhoea, irregular periods or, in adolescent girls, hypermenorhoea. Haematological investigation would reveal elevated male androgens.
Option D is Incorrect. This would result in non-development of secondary sexual characteristics.
Option E is Incorrect. This results in amenorrhoea due to gonadal dysfunction and poor breast development. The patient has normal sexual characteristics.

Option E is Incorrect. This results in amenorrhoea due to gonadal dysfunction and poor breast development. The patient has normal sexual characteristics.
